title: Pad Thai (Authentic)
steps: Soak rice noodles in room temperature water for 25-30 minutes until they are pliable but still firm. Drain well and set aside.
In a small saucepan over low heat, combine tamarind paste, fish sauce, and palm sugar. Stir continuously for 2-3 minutes until the sugar dissolves completely and the sauce is well blended. Set aside.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat until it shimmers. Add minced garlic and stir-fry for 15-20 seconds until fragrant but not browned.
Add the shrimp to the wok and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until they turn pink and are just cooked through. Push everything to one side of the wok.
Crack the egg into the empty side of the wok. Break the yolk and scramble for about 30 seconds until just set, then mix with the shrimp.
Add the drained noodles to the wok. Pour the prepared sauce over the noodles and toss everything together for 2-3 minutes until the noodles are evenly coated and heated through.
Add the chives and bean sprouts. Stir-fry for another 1-2 minutes until the bean sprouts are slightly softened but still crunchy.
Transfer to a serving plate. Garnish with crushed peanuts and serve immediately with lime wedges on the side. Squeeze lime juice over the dish before eating.

title: Thai Green Curry
steps: Pour 1/3 of the coconut milk (about 130ml) into a wok or large pot. Heat over medium-high heat for 3-4 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the coconut oil separates and rises to the surface.
Add the green curry paste to the separated coconut milk. Stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until the paste becomes very fragrant and the oil turns slightly green.

Add the sliced chicken to the curry paste. Stir well to coat each piece with the paste. Cook for 3-4 minutes, stirring frequently, until the chicken is partially cooked and no longer pink on the outside.
Pour in the remaining coconut milk and chicken stock. Stir to combine everything. Bring to a gentle boil over medium heat.
Add the halved Thai eggplants to the curry. Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer for 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the eggplants are tender and the chicken is fully cooked.
Season with fish sauce and palm sugar. Taste and adjust the seasoning to balance salty, sweet, and spicy flavors.
Tear the kaffir lime leaves and add them to the curry along with Thai basil leaves and sliced red chilies. Stir gently and cook for another 1-2 minutes until the basil wilts.
Remove from heat and transfer to a serving bowl. Serve hot with steamed jasmine rice. The curry should have a vibrant green color and a creamy consistency.

title: Tom Yum Goong (Spicy Shrimp Soup)
steps: In a large pot, bring the chicken or shrimp stock to a rolling boil over high heat. Add the lemongrass pieces (bruised with the back of a knife), galangal slices, and torn kaffir lime leaves. Boil for 5 minutes to infuse the aromatics into the broth.
Add the halved straw mushrooms to the boiling broth. Reduce heat to medium and simmer for 3 minutes until the mushrooms are tender.
Add the peeled and deveined shrimp to the pot. Cook for 2-3 minutes, stirring gently, until the shrimp turn pink and curl up. Do not overcook or the shrimp will become rubbery.
Season the soup with fish sauce and chili paste (Nam Prik Pao). Stir well to dissolve the chili paste completely. Taste and adjust seasoning - it should be sour, spicy, and salty.
Turn off the heat immediately. Add fresh lime juice and crushed Thai chilies. The lime juice should be added off heat to preserve its fresh, tangy flavor.
If making the creamy version (Tom Yum Nam Khon), stir in evaporated milk until the soup turns a pale orange color. For clear version (Tom Yum Nam Sai), skip this step.
Ladle into serving bowls and garnish generously with fresh cilantro leaves. Serve immediately while piping hot. The soup should be aromatic, with a perfect balance of sour, spicy, and savory flavors.

title: Som Tam (Green Papaya Salad)
steps: In a large mortar, add the garlic cloves and Thai chilies. Pound them together for about 1-2 minutes until you get a rough paste. The chilies should be broken down but not completely smooth.
Add the palm sugar to the mortar. Continue pounding for another minute until the sugar dissolves and combines with the garlic-chili paste.
Add the dried shrimp and roasted peanuts. Pound lightly just to break them up slightly - about 10-15 gentle pounds. They should remain chunky for texture.
Add the long beans (cut into 1-inch pieces) and halved cherry tomatoes. Pound gently 5-6 times just to bruise them and release their juices. Don't mash them completely.

Add the shredded green papaya to the mortar. Using a spoon and pestle together, pound and toss the papaya gently for 2-3 minutes. The goal is to bruise the papaya so it absorbs the flavors, not to mash it.

Season with fish sauce, fresh lime juice, and tamarind juice. Use the spoon to mix and toss everything together, ensuring the dressing coats all the ingredients evenly. Taste and adjust - it should be a balance of spicy, sour, salty, and slightly sweet.

Transfer to a serving plate immediately. Som Tam is best eaten fresh and should not sit for long. Serve with sticky rice, grilled chicken, or as a side dish. The salad should be crunchy, tangy, and refreshing.

title: Massaman Curry
steps: Pour the coconut cream into a large pot or wok. Heat over medium-high heat for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the coconut oil separates and rises to the top. You'll see a layer of clear oil forming.

Add the Massaman curry paste to the separated coconut cream. Fry the paste for 3-4 minutes, stirring constantly, until it becomes very fragrant and darkens slightly in color. The kitchen should smell wonderfully aromatic.
Add the cubed beef chuck to the pot. Stir well to coat each piece with the curry paste. Cook for 5-6 minutes, turning the beef occasionally, until all sides are browned and sealed.
Pour in the coconut milk. Add the bay leaves, cinnamon stick, and cardamom pods. Stir everything together and bring to a gentle boil over medium heat.

Once boiling, reduce heat to low. Cover and simmer gently for 30-40 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the beef is tender. Check by piercing with a fork - it should go in easily but the meat shouldn't fall apart.
Add the cubed potatoes and quartered onion to the curry. Stir gently and continue simmering uncovered for another 15-20 minutes until the potatoes are cooked through and tender.

Season the curry with fish sauce, palm sugar, and tamarind paste. Stir well and taste. Adjust the seasoning to achieve a balance of salty, sweet, and slightly sour flavors. Massaman should be mildly sweet.
Add the roasted peanuts and stir them in. Simmer for a final 5 minutes to allow the peanuts to soften slightly and absorb the curry flavors.
Remove from heat. Transfer to a serving bowl and serve hot with steamed jasmine rice. The curry should be rich, creamy, and have a beautiful reddish-brown color with a layer of oil on top.
